awd_titl_txt: Multicentury records of ENSO and rainfall in corals from northern Australia

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we use the geochemistry and skeletal aspects of long-lived corals to develop histories of climate at three sites in northern Australia. These corals began growing in the mid-late 1700’s: they form large semi-spherical colonies made of calcium carbonate whose chemistry reflects the conditions under which they lived. We used cores through these corals that extend from the moment of sampling (the 1980’s-90’s in our case) back to the time of the coral’s earliest years, and we subsampled these at approximately monthly resolution. In our data, we see changes in chemistry (and thus the environment) that range from seasonal cycles to century-long trends. The strongest single climate influence on our records is the large seasonal-multidecadal variability in rainfall associated with the regional monsoon. The most consistent geochemical proxy is the skeletal oxygen isotopic content (hereafter δ18O), which we interpret as changes in seawater δ18O related to local factors (rainfall and ocean circulation) and larger-scale causes of changes (e.g. the Pacific El Niño/Southern Oscillation [ENSO] system, which impacts the region’s climate). We also explore the luminescence of the coral skeleton: under UV light, the skeletons exhibit annual fluorescing bands that result from organic material carried by rivers. Years of high discharge show larger/brighter bands than years of low discharge.

All our corals reveal past environmental variability, but each in a slightly different way.

1. Nightcliff Reef lies in the Timor Strait near Darwin (Australia), which is strongly influenced by the the Indonesian Throughflow (ITF) current - a major component of the global ocean circulation. The ITF passes through Indonesia and carries relatively warm and fresh waters into the Indian Ocean; the ITF is stronger when the tropical Pacific is cool (La Nina events). In addition, this region experiences stronger than normal rainfall during La Niña events. Both rainfall and strong ITF contribute waters that carry unusually low δ18O values. Our δ18O record from Nightcliff tracks Pacific interannual (ENSO) and decadal (IPO) variability as a combination of these two factors.

  • Key outcome: we provide estimates of Pacific variability that show no increases in ENSO strength, and that can improve large-scale Pacific climate reconstructions.

 

2. Using a coral from Jeannie River, far north Queensland (Australia), we have generated records that are highly sensitive to local and regional rainfall. We find strong correlations between regional rainfall and 4 independent measures from the coral (δ18Osw, δ13C, Ba/Ca, and skeletal luminescence). Using all of these records, we calculate a robust index of monsoon-season rainfall that extends to 1746 CE. Our reconstruction extends previous work by our collaborator (Dr. Janice Lough), whose well-established Queensland rainfall reconstruction does not include far north Queensland.

  • Key outcomes: We find that north Queensland rainfall has become more intense since 1900, consistent with other records from nearby regions and with climate model projections of tropical rainfall in a warming world. We also find that particularly rainy years are often preceded by especially warm SST in the southwest Pacific (near New Caledonia/Fiji), suggesting the potential to improve predictions of north Queensland rainfall.

 

3. A coral from Bramble Cay, in the Gulf of Papua (Australia), is strongly influenced by large changes in salinity associated with the nearby Fly River that drains the New Guinea highlands. Coral δ18O data correlate with Pacific climate variability (ENSO and decadal variability); this correlation is significant in the wet season, and much lower during other seasons, attesting to the importance of subannual resolution. We find an unusual luminescence signal, in which values are consistently high except in drought years (this is still being quantified).

  • Key outcome: The interannual variance of Bramble Cay δ18O correlates with ENSO and suggests no major trend in ENSO strength between 1774-1983, and the frequency of large droughts in the catchment does not show a major trend.

4. We analyzed a commonly used proxy for sea surface temperature, the ratio of strontium (Sr) to calcium (Ca) or Sr/Ca, in all cores. Although we see clear seasonal cycles as expected, the year to year and longer-term variations in coral Sr/Ca do not correlate with observed temperatures. Several factors may contribute to this lack of relationship, including changes in seawater Sr/Ca associated with river discharge and the low level of year-to-year change in local SST, which may be undetectable given these regional complexities.

Our project has also contributed to training and workforce development by engaging undergraduate (6), pre-graduate (1), and graduate students (2), along with early career researchers (2) in hands-on research. They have presented work orally and in papers. The PI has also presented this work to scientific audiences, and used it to inform more general presentations and media exchanges about the state of coral reefs and climate change. Finally, our data will be provided to the Australian Institute of Marine Science, whose mission is management of Australia's coral reefs.
